title-group.article-title: Utility of Post–Urinary Tract Infection Imaging in Patients With Normal Prenatal Renal Ultrasound

article-meta.aff: 2New York University, New York, NY, USA

author-notes.corresp: Jun Sasaki, Miami Children’s Hospital, 3100 SW 62nd Avenue, Miami, FL 33134, USA Email: junsasaki41@gmail.com

abstract.p: The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends renal ultrasound (RUS) and voiding cystourethrography (VCUG) for all infants after a first urinary tract infection (UTI). However, many congenital renal anomalies are identified by a prenatal US. At the present time, there are no data regarding the yield of post-UTI imaging among infants who have a documented normal prenatal US. We retrospectively reviewed the charts of all patients <1 year of age with a first UTI who had normal kidneys noted on prenatal US to determine the frequency of abnormal findings. Abnormal RUS and VCUG results were noted in 5.1% (24 of 471) and 20.4% (75 of 368) of infants, respectively. While the abnormal US rate is significantly less than what has been previously reported, the frequency of abnormal VCUGs is similar. These results suggest that a post-UTI RUS may not be needed if the prenatal US was normal. However, a VCUG continues to be indicated.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends renal ultrasound (RUS) and voiding cystourethrography (VCUG) for all infants after a first urinary tract infection (UTI).1 The RUS can detect anatomical abnormalities of the urinary tract, such as hydronephrosis and hydroureter, while the VCUG can determine the presence and grade of vesicoureteral reflux. This information can guide ongoing patient management in terms of antimicrobial prophylaxis and surgical intervention.1,2

Most infants born in the United States have a prenatal US so that many congenital renal anomalies are identified before birth. Therefore, the incidence of occult renal disease in young infants is probably lower than what is published in older literature. Hoberman et al3 and Zamir et al4 evaluated the value of post-UTI imaging studies in the general population without regard to prenatal information, while Montini et al5 in Italy and Miron et al6 in Israel assessed selected populations with a history of a normal level-2 prenatal US. The 2 American studies provide a historical comparison to the general population in the United States, while the international studies investigated a preselected population of children with normal prenatal anatomy. All 4 studies concluded that RUS was of limited value in the management of patients with febrile UTIs. No previous study has assessed the incidence of abnormal post-UTI imaging in American patients with normal prenatal RUS.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: We conducted a retrospective multicenter chart review study at 3 New York City Health and Hospital Corporation (HHC) facilities (Elmhurst Hospital Center, Bellevue Hospital Center, and Jacobi Medical Center). The study was approved by the NYC HHC institutional review board. The data collected were patient age, gender, and post-UTI RUS and VCUG results.

sec.title: Subjects
sec.p: We included all patients <1 year of age who fulfilled the following criteria:

list-item.p: Born at 1 of the 3 study hospitals
Had a first febrile UTI diagnosed at 1 of the study hospitals between January 2004 and September 2009
Had normal kidneys noted during a routine anatomical prenatal US performed between 17 and 22 weeks gestation
Had a post-UTI RUS and/or VCUG

sec.title: Exclusions

list-item.p: Prenatal US performed after 22 weeks gestation or a suboptimal image obtained
Radiology reports unavailable for the prenatal US and/or post-UTI imaging studies

sec.p: We determined the yield of post-UTI imaging in this specific population and compared the results with the existing literature3-6 on post-UTI imaging. We combined the 2 US studies (Hoberman et al3 and Zamir et al4) and the 2 international studies (Montini et al5 and Miron et al6) for historical cohorts.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: A total of 471 patients met the inclusion criteria: 310 males and 161 females. Twenty-four (5.1%) patients had an abnormal post-UTI RUS (Table 1). Only 368 patients had a post-UTI VCUG, of which 75 (20.4%) were abnormal (Table 2). As shown in Tables 3 and 4, our subjects had a significantly lower rate of abnormal post-UTI RUS (5.1%) than in previous studies with unselected populations3,4 (5.1% vs 13.5%, P < .001) and 8.6% in international studies with selected populations5,6 (5.1% vs 8.6%, P = .04). However, the rate of abnormal VCUGs was not different when compared with the unselected and selected populations (20.4% vs 29.7% and 24.2%, respectively, P = ns).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: We found that the RUS is normal in the majority of infants ≤1 year of age with a febrile UTI who had a previously normal prenatal US at 17 to 22 weeks gestation. However, there was no difference in the rate of abnormal VCUGs. Our subjects were all <1 year old, while the comparison studies included patients >1 year of age, a group that is known to have a dramatically lower rate of abnormal RUS. Therefore, our results are likely to be more statistically significant when only patients ≤1 year of age are considered. Our data therefore suggest that a post-UTI RUS may not be necessary for a febrile patient ≤1 year of age with afebrile UTI and a history of a normal prenatal US at 17 to 22 weeks gestation. In contrast, since there was no difference in the rate of abnormal VCUGs, a normal prenatal US cannot be used to exclude the possibility of vesicoureteral reflux.

Our study has several limitations. It is retrospective, our inclusion and exclusion criteria may not have been ideal, and it is possible that children with serious genitourinary abnormalities received care at other non-HHC hospitals in New York City. In addition, we used the common screening prenatal US and not higher level prenatal US that was performed in the international studies. While the higher level prenatal US scans are not routine for all pregnancies in the United States, it is possible that such studies would have identified more prenatal kidney disease and therefore excluded patients from our study.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Our study further questions the clinical need for a post-UTI RUS, while reinforcing the utility of the VCUG. A prospective study is warranted to confirm these results and assess the cost–benefit ratio of the various post-UTI imaging studies.
